Observation regarding silver.  The run coincides with the drop in $BTC .  This makes me think that's where the bulk of silver's recent run came from, especially given that a lot of money is still in stocks and real estate.  Let's say this is correct, and let's take it to the extreme.  If all of crypto's money went to silver, that's almost $3 trillion, which would be good for silver, but after that money dries up, in order to keep silver going, the money will have to come from somewhere else.  The stock market and real estate bubbles are crazy swollen right now.  If money were to leave those bubbles, all it takes is a couple -3% or -4% days for panic to set in.  If there's panic, that can send most assets down, including precious metals.  Especially if people initially prefer treasuries and money markets as their favorite safe havens.  Having said all this, there will be a point after fleeing to safety when people will want to have action again.  The question then will be where to have action.  It's my view that I might still like crypto because if there is a lot of technological potential with some of these ventures, an asset class that is under $3 trillion, if it in fact has intrinsic value, that's the most UNDERsaturated asset of anything in the world.  So I conclude that I like safety now, but would later consider the best value cryptos I can find.

Async Payjoin, the HTTPS of Bitcoin Privacy .  Async Payjoin is the best hope for strong privacy in $BTC  . Modeled after HTTPS, which enabled secure payments for the web, the Payjoin foundation has been quietly building up this privacy toolkit, which must be adopted by a large number of Bitcoin wallets, to deliver privacy at scale.   Modeled after the Bitcoin and Lightning dev kits, which have become quite popular among wallet developers and built with the same cryptographic primitives already in Bitcoin core, such that it can be easily integrated into the main Bitcoin implementation, Async Payjoin is designed from the bottom up for mass adoption. $BTC SHOCKING SIGNAL: Global Money Supply Just Went Vertical

Liquidity is flooding the system ‚Äî and history says Bitcoin doesn‚Äôt ignore this. Across the board, U.S., Japan, China, and Europe money supply curves are ripping higher, printing near-vertical expansions. This isn‚Äôt localized easing. It‚Äôs a global liquidity wave.

When money supply accelerates this fast, capital looks for scarce, liquid assets. That‚Äôs where Bitcoin enters the conversation. BTC has consistently acted as a high-beta response to global liquidity growth, lagging at first‚Ä¶ then catching up violently.

Right now, the disconnect is obvious. Fiat supply is exploding, while Bitcoin is still digesting recent volatility. That gap doesn‚Äôt stay open forever. Historically, BTC moves after liquidity turns ‚Äî not before.

If this expansion continues, the path of least resistance points higher.

From 1 January 2026, the centralized cryptocurrency exchange Binance, in order to ensure its own survival and under pressure from new UK regulations, will be required to fully transfer user information and data related to crypto assets to the tax authorities. In this process, Binance has openly created a link encouraging users to carry this out voluntarily.

Under these circumstances, users should be aware that using centralized platforms, particularly with full identity verification, means losing control over their financial data and being subjected to mandatory transparency of their economic activities.


The responsibility for awareness and final decision-making rests with the users themselves.

MicroStrategy co-founder Michael Saylor said in a December 20 interview with CoinDesk that the evolution of Bitcoin treasury companies is not centered on asset speculation, but on the creation of digital credit. Why impulsive pumps often fail?  Most traders are taught to react to price.‚Ä®Very few are taught to read positioning. When price suddenly spikes, it‚Äôs tempting to assume strength.‚Ä®But impulsive pumps are often the weakest moves in the market. Here‚Äôs why. First, look at Open Interest (OI).‚Ä®If price moves up while OI expands rapidly, it usually means leverage is being added ‚Äî not spot demand. New positions are opening into the move, chasing momentum. Then check CVD (Cumulative Volume Delta).‚Ä®If CVD continues to trend down or fails to confirm the pump, buyers are not aggressive. Market buys are being absorbed. Price is moving, but real demand isn‚Äôt following. Now add Funding Rate.‚Ä®During impulsive pumps, funding often flips strongly positive. That tells you who is paying ‚Äî late longs. The more crowded one side becomes, the more fragile the move is. Finally, the most overlooked piece: Liquidity Heatmap.‚Ä®Impulsive pumps often run directly into sell-side liquidity or large resting orders. These levels are not targets for continuation ‚Äî they‚Äôre areas where positions get distributed or trapped. So what usually happens? ‚Ä¢ The initial breakout attracts retail longs‚Ä® ‚Ä¢ Liquidity sits above and below the range‚Ä® ‚Ä¢ Market makers sell into strength‚Ä® ‚Ä¢ Price reverses or stalls‚Ä® ‚Ä¢ Late entrants get chopped or liquidated This doesn‚Äôt mean every pump must fail.‚Ä®It means pumps without structural support rarely sustain. That‚Äôs why I focus on structure, positioning, and liquidity, not predictions or emotions.‚Ä®The market doesn‚Äôt reward speed ‚Äî it rewards understanding. Latest market news shows that Grayscale expects that the bipartisan-promoted cryptocurrency market structure bill in the US is likely to be officially passed in 2026. This judgment has quickly sparked heated discussions in the crypto community and is seen by many investors as a significant institutional benefit in the medium to long term.
From a background perspective, the current US cryptocurrency regulation has long been in a "gray area", with unclear responsibilities between the SEC and CFTC, enforcement ahead of rules, and delayed regulations, which has become the biggest uncertainty for institutional entrants. The core goal of this market structure bill is to clarify the regulatory boundaries of digital assets, asset classification, and compliance paths for trading platforms, establishing "basic rules" for the crypto market similar to traditional finance.
Grayscale believes that once the bill is enacted, the first beneficiaries will be institutional funds. Pension funds, insurance funds, sovereign funds, and other long-term capital will have clearer compliance bases to enter the on-chain world. At the same time, compliant exchanges, custodians, and on-chain financial infrastructure will also welcome a new round of expansion, driving real trading volumes and on-chain activities to grow in sync.
More importantly, this legislative signal itself has the significance of "expectation management". It means that the US policy stance towards the cryptocurrency industry is gradually shifting from "risk prevention" to "regulatable and developable". For the entire industry, this is not only a possibility for regulatory easing but also an important step towards integrating crypto assets into the mainstream financial system. $BTC
